_**War for the Planet of the Apes**_ is a 2017 American [science fiction
film](/wiki/Science_fiction_film "Science fiction film") directed by [Matt
Reeves](/wiki/Matt_Reeves "Matt Reeves") and written by [Mark
Bomback](/wiki/Mark_Bomback "Mark Bomback") and Reeves. A sequel to _[Rise of
the Planet of the Apes](/wiki/Rise_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Rise of the
Planet of the Apes")_ (2011) and _[Dawn of the Planet of the
Apes](/wiki/Dawn_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Dawn of the Planet of the Apes")_
(2014), it is the third installment in the _[Planet of the
Apes](/wiki/Planet_of_the_Apes "Planet of the Apes")_ [reboot
series](/wiki/Planet_of_the_Apes#Reboot_film_series "Planet of the Apes"). The
film stars [Andy Serkis](/wiki/Andy_Serkis "Andy Serkis"), [Woody
Harrelson](/wiki/Woody_Harrelson "Woody Harrelson") and [Steve
Zahn](/wiki/Steve_Zahn "Steve Zahn"), and follows a confrontation between the
apes, led by [Caesar](/wiki/List_of_Planet_of_the_Apes_characters#Caesar "List
of Planet of the Apes characters"), and the humans for control of Earth. Like
its predecessor, its premise shares several similarities to the fifth film in
the original series, _[Battle for the Planet of the
Apes](/wiki/Battle_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Battle for the Planet of the
Apes")_ , but it is not a direct remake.

[Principal photography](/wiki/Principal_photography "Principal photography")
began on October 14, 2015, in [Vancouver, British
Columbia](/wiki/Vancouver,_British_Columbia "Vancouver, British Columbia"),
Canada. _War for the Planet of the Apes_ premiered in [New York
City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") on July 10, 2017, and was
theatrically released in the United States on July 14, 2017, by [20th Century
Fox](/wiki/20th_Century_Fox "20th Century Fox").[5] The film has grossed over
$490 million and received critical praise, with many reviewers highlighting
the performances (particularly Serkis), visual effects, story, direction, and
musical score. The film received a nomination for [Best Special Visual
Effects](/wiki/BAFTA_Award_for_Best_Special_Visual_Effects "BAFTA Award for
Best Special Visual Effects") at the [71st British Academy Film
Awards](/wiki/71st_British_Academy_Film_Awards "71st British Academy Film
Awards")[6], and was also nominated for [Best Visual
Effects](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Visual_Effects "Academy Award for Best
Visual Effects") at the [90th Academy Awards](/wiki/90th_Academy_Awards "90th
Academy Awards").[7]

##
Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=War_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Plot")]

Two years have passed[8] since the human-hating [bonobo](/wiki/Bonobo
"Bonobo") Koba attacked [the human survivors in San
Francisco](/wiki/Dawn_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Dawn of the Planet of the
Apes"). Forcing Caesar and his tribe of intelligent apes against a rogue U.S.
military faction known as Alpha-Omega. Led by a ruthless Colonel, Alpha-Omega
employs many apes formerly loyal to Koba. These apes are derogatorily called
"donkeys".

An attack by an Alpha-Omega platoon on an ape colony is rebuffed when Caesar
rallies his apes in defense. Capturing alive a soldier named Preacher, three
other soldiers and "donkey" [gorilla](/wiki/Gorilla "Gorilla") named Red,
Caesar explains that he executed Koba for causing the war and only desires
peace. Caesar then releases the soldiers, hoping the display of mercy will
show the Colonel that the apes are not savages. Meanwhile, Red escapes by
injuring the albino gorilla Winter.

While ceremonially disposing of the dead apes, Caesar welcomes back his eldest
son Blue Eyes and his lieutenant Rocket from a long journey. Blue Eyes reports
that they have found a place across the [desert](/wiki/Desert "Desert") that
is ideal for them. An uneasy Winter beseeches that the tribe leave
immediately. Though agreeing to leave, Caesar feels they need to prepare
first. That night, the Colonel leads a team of soldiers in infiltrating the
ape’s home. Believing he had succeeded, the Colonel begins to leave only to be
discovered by Caesar. Enraged upon seeing that the human killed his wife
Cornelia and son, he attempts to prevent the Colonel's escape but fails. After
the attack the apes cannot find Winter.

In the morning, the tribe gathers to journey to safety. Leaving his youngest
son, Cornelius, in the care of Blue Eyes' wife Lake, Caesar departs to exact
revenge while serving as the decoy for the other apes. Accompanied by his
[orangutan](/wiki/Orangutan "Orangutan") adviser Maurice, gorilla lieutenant
Luca, and Rocket, the apes enter an abandoned village where they kill a
deserted soldier in self-defense. Searching the village the apes discover a
mute girl. Maurice befriends and adopts the girl, giving her a small [rag
doll](/wiki/Rag_doll "Rag doll").

At a beach side military camp, the apes spot Winter inside and the group sneak
in. Winter, who became a "donkey", tells Caesar that the Colonel has departed
for the border, to meet soldiers from the north. Winter attempts to call out
for help but the apes restrain him and in the struggle Caesar accidentally
kills him. In the morning the military breaks camp and the apes follow. Along
the way, the apes discover some soldiers who have been shot and left for dead.
Their examination of a surviving soldier reveals that he is mute like the
girl. Dying from his wounds, Caesar [kills](/wiki/Euthanasia "Euthanasia") him
in an act of mercy.

Climbing atop a radio tower, the apes search for direction the soldier’s
traveled. During this, a hooded figure steals one of their horses and the apes
give chase. Ending at a lodge, the apes corner the figure who is revealed to
be a chimpanzee named Bad Ape. The group is surprised to discover he is an
intelligent ape but from another zoo. While camping with Bad Ape they discover
he knows where the border is and he hesitantly agrees to lead them there. The
group reach the border where they see a quarantine facility. When attempting
to get a closer look, Luca is killed protecting Caesar from some soldiers. An
angered Caesar decides to proceed alone rather than endanger his allies
further.

At the facility, Caesar learns that Alpha-Omega captured his tribe and are
forcing them to build a wall without food or water. Caesar is then captured by
Red who brings him to the Colonel. The Colonel tells Caesar that he intended
to kill him rather than his son and wife. With an act of defiance Caesar
causes the other apes to stop working but the Colonel threatens to kill Caesar
to get the apes to continue working. Caesar deduces that the Colonel is
barricading the facility to fend off other military who are against him for
killing his own soldiers. The Colonel commends Caesar's intelligence and goes
on to tell Caesar that the Simian Flu virus had mutated and the human carriers
became mute and [devolved](/wiki/Devolution_\(biology\) "Devolution
\(biology\)") into a primitive state. The mutation infecting his only son, The
Colonel killed him and ordered his men to kill anyone that happens to be
infected or defies his instruction. A survivor of this purge told the military
in the north who sent men to relieve the Colonel of his command. The Colonel
says he spared one person to give a message to the military to come after him
at the facility. The Colonel knows that the facility used to be a weapons
depot and plans on using it’s resources to fight off the military. Finally the
Colonel declares that he is fighting a "[holy war](/wiki/Religious_war
"Religious war")" for humanity's survival and redemption.

Caesar is tortured with starvation to force his clan to work. The mute girl
sneaks into the facility to give Caesar food, water, and her rag doll. To
prevent her from being discovered, Rocket allows himself to be captured as a
diversion. The next day, the Colonel comes to see if Caesar is still alive,
and confiscates the doll upon discovering it. Together, Caesar and Rocket are
able to work out a means of escape via an underground tunnel leading out of
the facility. Here Maurice names the girl Nova, and along with Bad Ape use the
tunnel to rescue the apes, but Caesar remains behind to settle his affair with
the Colonel as the facility comes under attack by the northern army. Caesar
finds the Colonel has been infected by the virus from contact with Nova's
doll. Caesar chooses not to kill the Colonel, instead watching him commit
[suicide](/wiki/Suicide "Suicide") with his [pistol](/wiki/Pistol "Pistol").

The escaping apes are caught in the crossfire between the two armies. Red
watches the apes suffering and begins to doubt his allegiance to Alpha-Omega.
Caesar attempts to blow up a large fuel tank to take out the Alpha-Omega
forces from behind but he is shot with a [crossbow](/wiki/Crossbow "Crossbow")
by Preacher. Red uses a [grenade launcher](/wiki/Grenade_launcher "Grenade
launcher") to kill Preacher and saves Caesar's life but is shot dead by a
soldier. Caesar succeeds in blowing up the fuel tank and escapes the facility
as it is consumed in cascade of explosions. The victorious northern army
notices Caesar but before they can kill him, an [avalanche](/wiki/Avalanche
"Avalanche") descends upon the base. The apes, carrying Nova, all survive by
climbing nearby trees. The apes then cross the desert to find an
[oasis](/wiki/Oasis "Oasis"). While the other apes joyously celebrate their
new home, Maurice discovers Caesar's fatal arrow wound. Maurice promises to
tell Cornelius who his father was and what he did for their tribe. Caesar then
slowly and silently succumbs to his wounds, dying peacefully while Maurice and
the other apes look on.

Cast[[edit](/w/index.php?title=War_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Cast")]

###
Apes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=War_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Apes")]

  * [Andy Serkis](/wiki/Andy_Serkis "Andy Serkis") as [Caesar](/wiki/List_of_Planet_of_the_Apes_characters#Caesar "List of Planet of the Apes characters"), an intelligent [common chimpanzee](/wiki/Common_chimpanzee "Common chimpanzee") who is leader to a tribe of genetically enhanced apes.[9]
  * [Steve Zahn](/wiki/Steve_Zahn "Steve Zahn") as "Bad Ape", a common chimpanzee who lived in a zoo before the Simian Flu outbreak, and was a hermit before joining Caesar's group.[10][11]
  * [Karin Konoval](/wiki/Karin_Konoval "Karin Konoval") as Maurice, a [Bornean orangutan](/wiki/Bornean_orangutan "Bornean orangutan") who is Caesar's adviser.[9]
  * [Terry Notary](/wiki/Terry_Notary "Terry Notary") as Rocket, a common chimpanzee who is Caesar's brother-figure.[12]
  * [Ty Olsson](/wiki/Ty_Olsson "Ty Olsson") as Red, a [Western lowland gorilla](/wiki/Western_lowland_gorilla "Western lowland gorilla") who was once a follower of Koba, now serving the Colonel to defeat Caesar. Olsson previously played Chief Hamill in _[Rise](/wiki/Rise_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Rise of the Planet of the Apes")_.[13]
  * [Michael Adamthwaite](/wiki/Michael_Adamthwaite "Michael Adamthwaite") as Luca, a Western lowland gorilla in Caesar's tribe.[14]
  * [Toby Kebbell](/wiki/Toby_Kebbell "Toby Kebbell") as Koba, a [bonobo](/wiki/Bonobo "Bonobo") who had previously waged war against the humans in _[Dawn of the Planet of the Apes](/wiki/Dawn_of_the_Planet_of_the_Apes "Dawn of the Planet of the Apes")_ , now appears in Caesar's hallucinations.
  * [Judy Greer](/wiki/Judy_Greer "Judy Greer") as Cornelia, Caesar's wife.[9]
  * [Sara Canning](/wiki/Sara_Canning "Sara Canning") as Lake, a common chimpanzee in Caesar's tribe, who is also Blue Eyes' mate and later Cornelius's caretaker.[15]
  * Max Lloyd-Jones as Blue Eyes, Caesar and Cornelia's oldest son.[16]
  * [Devyn Dalton](/wiki/Devyn_Dalton "Devyn Dalton") as Cornelius, Caesar and Cornelia's youngest son, and Blue Eyes' younger brother. Dalton previously played Cornelia in _Rise_.
  * [Aleks Paunovic](/wiki/Aleks_Paunovic "Aleks Paunovic") as Winter, an [albino](/wiki/Albinism_in_biology "Albinism in biology") Western lowland gorilla in Caesar's tribe who sided with the Colonel out of fear.[17]

###
Humans[[edit](/w/index.php?title=War_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Humans")]

  * [Woody Harrelson](/wiki/Woody_Harrelson "Woody Harrelson") as Colonel J. Wesley McCollough, the leader of the paramilitary organization Alpha-Omega, who is obsessed with wiping out Caesar and his tribe to preserve humans as the dominant species.[18][19]
  * Amiah Miller as Nova, a mute orphan whom Maurice befriends and cares for.[20][21]
  * [Gabriel Chavarria](/wiki/Gabriel_Chavarria "Gabriel Chavarria") as Preacher, a human soldier working under the Colonel in Alpha-Omega.[22]

##
Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=War_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Production")]

###
Development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=War_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Development")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/5/5e/War_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes_in_New_York_Comic_Con_2016.jpg/200px-
War_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes_in_New_York_Comic_Con_2016.jpg)](/wiki/File:War_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes_in_New_York_Comic_Con_2016.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:War_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes_in_New_York_Comic_Con_2016.jpg
"Enlarge")

[Matt Reeves](/wiki/Matt_Reeves "Matt Reeves"), [Andy
Serkis](/wiki/Andy_Serkis "Andy Serkis") and Dylan Clark at [New York Comic-
Con](/wiki/New_York_Comic-Con "New York Comic-Con") 2016 for the _War for the
Planet of the Apes_ panel

After seeing his cut of _Dawn_ , [20th Century Fox](/wiki/20th_Century_Fox
"20th Century Fox") and [Chernin Entertainment](/wiki/Chernin_Entertainment
"Chernin Entertainment") signed [Matt Reeves](/wiki/Matt_Reeves "Matt Reeves")
to return as director for a third installment of the reboot series. In January
2014, the studio announced the third film, with Reeves returning to direct and
co-write along with Bomback, and Peter Chernin, Rick Jaffa and Amanda Silver
serving as producers.[23][24] During an interview in mid-November 2014 with
[MTV](/wiki/MTV "MTV"), Andy Serkis said they did not know the next film's
setting. "...It could be five years after the event. It could be the night
after the events of where we left '_Dawn_.'"[25] In May 2015, the title was
first given as _War of the Planet of the Apes_.[26] By October 2015, it had
been retitled as _War for the Planet of the Apes_.[10]

When director Reeves and screenwriter Bomback came on board to helm _Dawn_ ,
the film already had a release date, which led to an accelerated production
schedule. However, with the third installment, Fox wanted to give the duo
plenty of time to write and make the film. Taking advantage of this, the two
bonded with each other more than before.[27]

In interviews for _Dawn_ , Reeves talked about the inevitable war Caesar would
have with the humans: "As this story continues, we know that war is not
avoided by the end of _Dawn_. That is going to take us into the world of what
he is grappling with. Where he is going to be thrust into circumstances that
he never, ever wanted to deal with, and was hoping he could avoid. And now he
is right in the middle of it. The things that happen in that story test him in
huge ways, in the ways in which his relationship with Koba haunts him deeply.
It’s going to be an epic story. I think you’ve probably read that I sort of
described it where in the first film was very much about his rise from humble
beginnings to being a revolutionary. The second movie was about having to rise
to the challenge of being a great leader in the most difficult of times. This
is going to be the story that is going to cement his status as a seminal
figure in ape history, and sort of leads to an almost biblical status. He is
going to become like a mythic ape figure, like [Moses](/wiki/Moses
"Moses")."[28]

[Toby Kebbell](/wiki/Toby_Kebbell "Toby Kebbell"), who portrayed Koba in
_Dawn_ , had expressed interest in reprising his role or performing as other
characters.[29] Plans to include Koba in a larger role in the film were
abandoned early, with Bomback saying, "If you stayed until the very end of
_Dawn of the Planet of the Apes_ , you hear Koba’s breathing. We did that to
give us a tiny crack of a possibility that we could revive Koba if we wanted
to. Very early on in spitballing, we realized there was nothing more to do
with Koba – certainly nothing that would exceed what he had done in the last
story. But we knew we wanted to keep him alive as an idea. In playing out the
reality of what happened at the end of the last film, Caesar would be
traumatized by having to kill his brother. That would have resonance, and we
wanted to make sure that did not get lost. So the answer was that we could go
inside Caesar’s mind at this point and revisit Koba that way."[30]

###
Casting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=War_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Casting")]

In August 2015, [Deadline](/wiki/Deadline.com "Deadline.com") reported that
[Gabriel Chavarria](/wiki/Gabriel_Chavarria "Gabriel Chavarria") had been cast
as one of the humans in the film.[31] In September 2015, _[The Hollywood
Reporter](/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter "The Hollywood Reporter")_ announced
that [Woody Harrelson](/wiki/Woody_Harrelson "Woody Harrelson") had been cast
as the film's antagonist, and that Chavarria's role was supporting.[18] In
October 2015, [TheWrap](/wiki/TheWrap "TheWrap") reported that [Steve
Zahn](/wiki/Steve_Zahn "Steve Zahn") was cast as a new ape in the film.[10] It
was also announced that actress Amiah Miller was cast as one of the film's
humans, with [Judy Greer](/wiki/Judy_Greer "Judy Greer") and [Karin
Konoval](/wiki/Karin_Konoval "Karin Konoval") reprising their roles as
Cornelia and Maurice,[9][20] while [Aleks Paunovic](/wiki/Aleks_Paunovic
"Aleks Paunovic") and [Sara Canning](/wiki/Sara_Canning "Sara Canning") were
cast as new apes.[17][15]

###
Filming[[edit](/w/index.php?title=War_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Filming")]

[Principal photography](/wiki/Principal_photography "Principal photography")
on the film began on October 14, 2015 in the [Lower
Mainland](/wiki/Lower_Mainland "Lower Mainland") in
[Vancouver](/wiki/Vancouver "Vancouver"), under the working title _Hidden
Fortress_.[32][33] Filming was expected to take place there until early March
2016.[34] Parts of the film were expected to shoot for up to five days in the
[Kananaskis](/wiki/Kananaskis_Range "Kananaskis Range") in late January and
early February.[35] In March, Serkis confirmed that he had finished shooting
his portions.[36]

### Visual
effects[[edit](/w/index.php?title=War_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Visual effects")]

As with _Rise_ and _Dawn_ , the visual effects for _War_ were created by [Weta
Digital](/wiki/Weta_Digital "Weta Digital"); the apes were created with a
mixture of motion-capture and CGI key-frame animation, as they were performed
in motion-capture technology and animated in CGI.

##
Influences[[edit](/w/index.php?title=War_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Influences")]

At [New York Comic-Con](/wiki/New_York_Comic-Con "New York Comic-Con") 2016,
Reeves explained that he and Bomback were influenced by many films before
writing. He said, "One of the first things that Mark and I did because we had
just finished _Dawn_ was that we decided to watch a million movies. We decided
to do what people fantasize what Hollywood screenwriters get to do but no one
actually does. We got Fox to give us a theater and we watched movie after
movie. We watched every _Planet of the Apes_ movie, war movies, westerns,
_[Empire Strikes Back](/wiki/The_Empire_Strikes_Back "The Empire Strikes
Back")_... We just thought, 'We have to pretend we have all the time in the
world,' even though we had limited time. We got really inspired."[37]

Additionally, during production, Reeves and Bomback sought broader
inspirations from films like _[The Bridge on the River
Kwai](/wiki/The_Bridge_on_the_River_Kwai "The Bridge on the River Kwai")_ and
_[The Great Escape](/wiki/The_Great_Escape_\(film\) "The Great Escape
\(film\)")_. Feeling that there was a need to imbue Biblical themes and
elements, they also watched Biblical epics like _[Ben-Hur](/wiki/Ben-
Hur_\(1959_film\) "Ben-Hur \(1959 film\)")_ and _[The Ten
Commandments](/wiki/The_Ten_Commandments_\(1956_film\) "The Ten Commandments
\(1956 film\)")_. The influences and inspirations were made evident in the
relationship between Caesar and [Woody Harrelson](/wiki/Woody_Harrelson "Woody
Harrelson")'s Colonel, a military leader with pretensions toward godhood. The
parallels between Caesar as Moses and the Colonel as Pharaoh are quite
evident. Caesar arranges for the escape of his oppressed and enslaved fellow
apes. The oppressor army is totally destroyed by an overwhelming "sea" as in
the Exodus story. Finally, when Caesar and his clan reach the mountain
overlooking the "promised land" he dies--just as Moses did on Mt. Nebo. Reeves
indebtedness to the Exodus story is substantial. Reeves has compared their
relationship to the dynamic between [Alec Guinness](/wiki/Alec_Guinness "Alec
Guinness")'s British Commander and [Sessue Hayakawa](/wiki/Sessue_Hayakawa
"Sessue Hayakawa")'s prison camp Colonel in _Bridge on the River Kwai_.
Another comparison is in Caesar's journey to find the Colonel, flanked by a
posse of close friends – a situation Reeves explicitly tied to [Clint
Eastwood](/wiki/Clint_Eastwood "Clint Eastwood")'s war-weary soldier in _[The
Outlaw Josey Wales](/wiki/The_Outlaw_Josey_Wales "The Outlaw Josey
Wales")_.[27] Influences from the film _[Apocalypse Now](/wiki/Apocalypse_Now
"Apocalypse Now")_ , notably Harrelson's character and his Alpha-Omega faction
being similar to [Colonel Kurtz](/wiki/Colonel_Kurtz "Colonel Kurtz")'s
renegade army, were also noted by several journalists.[38][39][40] Harrelson
has also acknowledged the similarities and inspiration.[41]

On October 17, 2015, it was confirmed that [Michael
Giacchino](/wiki/Michael_Giacchino "Michael Giacchino"), the composer and
writer of the soundtrack for _Dawn_ , would return to compose _War_ 's
score.[42] The soundtrack was digitally released to [iTunes](/wiki/ITunes
"ITunes") and [Amazon](/wiki/Amazon.com "Amazon.com") on July 7, 2017,[43] and
in its physical form by [Sony Masterworks](/wiki/Sony_Masterworks "Sony
Masterworks") on July 21, 2017.[44]

##
Release[[edit](/w/index.php?title=War_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Release")]

The film was initially set for a July 29, 2016, release. However, in January
2015, Fox postponed the film's release date to about a year later on July 14,
2017.[45][5]

###
Marketing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=War_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Marketing")]

Special behind-the-scenes footage for the film was aired on TV on November 22,
2015, as part of a contest announcement presented by director [Matt
Reeves](/wiki/Matt_Reeves "Matt Reeves") and [Andy Serkis](/wiki/Andy_Serkis
"Andy Serkis").[46] The footage aired during _[The Walking
Dead](/wiki/The_Walking_Dead_\(TV_series\) "The Walking Dead \(TV series\)")_
on [AMC](/wiki/AMC_\(TV_channel\) "AMC \(TV channel\)").[47][48] The
announcement allowed winners to wear a performance-capture suit and appear in
a scene as an ape.[49] The announcement was released on 20th Century Fox's
official [YouTube](/wiki/YouTube "YouTube") page later the same day.[50]

At a [New York Comic Con](/wiki/New_York_Comic_Con "New York Comic Con")
special event on October 6, Reeves, Serkis and producer Dylan Clark debuted an
exclusive look at the film.[51]

Serkis has also mentioned that the film would be accompanied by a video game,
for which he performed motion capture.[52] Titled _[Planet of the Apes: Last
Frontier](/wiki/Planet_of_the_Apes:_Last_Frontier "Planet of the Apes: Last
Frontier")_ , the game was released for the [PlayStation
4](/wiki/PlayStation_4 "PlayStation 4"), [Xbox One](/wiki/Xbox_One "Xbox One")
and [PC](/wiki/Personal_computer "Personal computer") in fall 2017.[53]

### Home
media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=War_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Home media")]

_War for the Planet of the Apes_ was released on Digital HD on October 10,
2017, and on Blu-ray and DVD on October 24, 2017 by [20th Century Fox Home
Entertainment](/wiki/20th_Century_Fox_Home_Entertainment "20th Century Fox
Home Entertainment").[54]

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=War_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Reception")]

### Box
office[[edit](/w/index.php?title=War_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Box office")]

_War for the Planet of the Apes_ grossed $146.9 million in the United States
and Canada and $343.8 million in other territories for a worldwide total of
$490.7 million, against a production budget of $150 million.[4]

In North America, the film was projected to gross $50–60 million in its
opening weekend,[55] however, given its acclaimed status and strong word-of-
mouth, rival studios believed the film had the potential to debut as high as
$70–80 million.[3][56][57] _War_ was closely monitored by analysts while the
summer was witnessing a decline in ticket sales, a situation that they blamed
on franchise fatigue for an overabundance of sequels and reboots (such as
_[Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No
Tales](/wiki/Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_Dead_Men_Tell_No_Tales "Pirates of the
Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales")_ , _[Transformers: The Last
Knight](/wiki/Transformers:_The_Last_Knight "Transformers: The Last Knight")_
and _[The Mummy](/wiki/The_Mummy_\(2017_film\) "The Mummy \(2017 film\)")_).
However, box office analysts noted that well-reviewed films have tended to
perform in-line with estimates (_[Guardians of the Galaxy Vol.
2](/wiki/Guardians_of_the_Galaxy_Vol._2 "Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2")_ ,
_[Wonder Woman](/wiki/Wonder_Woman_\(2017_film\) "Wonder Woman \(2017
film\)")_ and _[Spider-Man: Homecoming](/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming "Spider-
Man: Homecoming")_).[58][59][60] The film grossed $5 million from Thursday
night previews at 3,021 theaters, up 22% from the $4.1 million earned by its
predecessor, and $22.1 million on its first day. It went on to debut to $56.3
million, topping the box office, albeit with a 22% drop from _Dawn_ 's $72.6
million debut.[61][62] In its second weekend, the film grossed $20.9 million
(a drop of 62.9%, more than the 50.4% fall _Dawn_ saw), finishing 4th at the
box office.[63] In its third weekend, the film made $10.5 million (dropping
another 49.9%), finishing 6th at the box office. It was lower than the third
weeks of both _Rise_ ($16.1 million) and _Dawn_ ($16.8 million).[64]

Outside North America, _War for the Planet of the Apes_ received a scattered
release in a span of three months (July–September). The film began its release
in about a third of the marketplace on July 14, albeit only in two major
markets, and was projected to have an opening of $50–60 million, with the
potential to go higher if smaller Asian markets over-perform, as they have for
recent tent poles.[3] The film ended up having an international debut of $44.2
million, including $9.27 million in the United Kingdom.[65]

### Critical
response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=War_for_the_Planet_of_the_Apes&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Critical response")]

_War for the Planet of the Apes_ received praise for the cast's performances
(particularly Serkis), Reeves's direction, visual effects, musical score,
cinematography and its morally complex storyline.[66] On [review
aggregator](/wiki/Review_aggregator "Review aggregator") site [Rotten
Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten Tomatoes"), the film has an approval
rating of 93% based on 294 reviews, with a [rating
average](/wiki/Weighted_arithmetic_mean "Weighted arithmetic mean") of 8.1/10.
The site's critical consensus reads, "_War for the Planet of the Apes_
combines breathtaking special effects and a powerful, poignant narrative to
conclude this rebooted trilogy on a powerful – and truly blockbuster –
note."[67] On review aggregator [Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic "Metacritic"),
which assigns a weighted average rating to reviews, the film has a score of 82
out of 100, based on 50 critics, indicating "universal acclaim".[68] Audiences
polled by [CinemaScore](/wiki/CinemaScore "CinemaScore") gave the film an
average grade of "A–" on an A+ to F scale, the same score earned by its two
immediate predecessors.[61]

Scott Collura of [IGN](/wiki/IGN "IGN") awarded the film a score of 9.5 out of
10, saying: "_War for the Planet of the Apes_ is an excellent closing act to
this rebooted trilogy, but also one that does enough world-building that the
series can potentially continue from here – and it’s a rare case where, after
three movies, we’re left wanting more."[69] [A.O. Scott](/wiki/A.O._Scott
"A.O. Scott") of _[The New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York
Times")_ said of the film, "_“War for the Planet of the Apes,”_ directed by
Matt Reeves, is the grimmest episode so far, and also the strongest, a superb
example — rare in this era of sloppily constructed, commercially hedged
cinematic universes — of clear thinking wedded to inventive technique in
popular filmmaking," and lauded Andy Serkis's performance in the film, stating
that "Andy Serkis’s performance as Caesar is one of the marvels of modern
screen acting."[70]

[Peter Travers](/wiki/Peter_Travers "Peter Travers") of _[Rolling
Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_ gave the film 3.5 out of 4 stars,
and said that Serkis performed "with a resonant power and depth of feeling
that's nearly Shakespearean. Oscar, get busy: Serkis deserves the gold," and
went on to say that "_War for the Planet of the Apes_ – No. 9 in the [simian
cinema canon](/wiki/Planet_of_the_Apes_\(franchise\) "Planet of the Apes
\(franchise\)") – is the best of the Apes films since the [1968
original](/wiki/Planet_of_the_Apes_\(1968_film\) "Planet of the Apes \(1968
film\)")."[71] Eric Kohn of _[Indiewire](/wiki/Indiewire "Indiewire")_ gave
the film a B+ rating, and praised Matt Reeves's directing, saying "It’s a
given that an expensive 21st century sci-fi movie with talking animals,
exploding tanks, and jarring machine guns would look and sound great, but
Reeves applies these effects with such a measured strategy that they’re always
working in service of a greater narrative agenda." Kohn went on to applaud the
visuals and musical score, stating that "The breathlessly paced montage of
flying bullets and angry monkeys raining down on terrified men, aided by
Michael Giacchino’s vibrant score, is a strong indicator of the next-level
craftsmanship that distinguishes these movies from so many cacophonous
Hollywood spectacles; not only is the action easy to follow, but you care for
the motion-captured characters at the center of it, while the humans cower in
fear."[72]
